MARTIAL AIRS AS WELL AS
fighting cries will fill the air tomorrow afternoon when the Blue Jay
stickmen meet their next opponent,
for the scene will be West Point, the
rival, the United States Military
academy.
Prospects for victory for the Hopkins ten are uncertain. Although
they were defeated in their last two
encounters, the Jays have improved
a great deal. The Army aggregation
has triumphed over St John's by a
7-4 count and the Joluudes subdued
Hopkins by 6-4. If comparative
, scores mean anything, the Jays
should be in for a sound drubbing.

Dr H S Jennings
speaks to Phi
Beta Kappa
TWENTY - EIGHT NEW MEMbers were initiated into the Alpha
Chapter of Maryland Phi Beta
Kappa, at initiation ceremonies held
last Friday night at the Hopkins
Faculty club. Dr 5 0 Mast, president of the local chapter, acted as
chairman, and Dr H S Jennings, director of the Hoftkins Zoological
Walters, prolaboratory, and
fessor of zoology gave the address.
Speaking on "Some Aspects of the
Nature of Man," Dr Jennings emphasized the uniqueness of almost
every individual making up society,
and the consequent conclusion, that
there can be no regular law laid
down either by natural scientists, or
by social scientists, to predict the
exact behavior of man at a given
time.

at Music club sponsored
dance in Levering hall
If the little green god that dwells
in the bell-tower of Gilman hall wills
the weather to he kind, June week
for the seniors and the undergraduates of this fair University should
be -the most glorious ever to breeze
away the memories of a tough examination session, the members of
the June week committee announce.
Billy Isaacs at the Musical club
melee on June 7, Jimmy Lunceford
slogging melody on the 8; the Senior
banquet on the 9; Paul Whiteman,
beauty contest, and Chesterfield
broadcast on the tenth. Then lulling
waves, and bright sunshine at the
Beach Club on the 11, will make
cross-marks on the calendars of the
biggest crowd ever to attend the
June week festivities.
Susan Lines, sub -debutante
daughter of, Mr and Mrs Frederick
Lines will have as escort during
- June week, Frank Grist, who will
introduce her as sponsor.,Her name
has been added to that of Christ, J.
Murray Kemptoh, editor of the NEWfk.,..

editor of the Blue Jay, as a fourth
judge of the June Week Beauty Contest. Three prizes will be awarded
in the contest, and twenty other contestants will receive "compensation",
In the form of honorable mention.
Thes will 'comprise the court of the
Queen of June week.
Billy Isaacs' band will hold sway
over the Musical club-sponsored-dance
from 9 to 1 at Levering hall. All
,proceeds will go to the Musical club.
1Smooth soiling and an ingenious
style", blurb the sponsors, "make
this Baltimore organization one of
the most popular with the Homewood crowd." This affair will set off
the starting gun for the Week, on
June 7.

The present Student council devoted much time and thought to the
trthancement of a well functioning
honor system. The Engineering and
the Arts and Sciences and Business
Schools Honor Commissions were
appointed. These appointments were
suggested and discussed by the council. The appointments were in no
sense political.
The Commissions
have functioned beautifully and have
produced material results in the educational drive toward honor. If I
have anything to do with either Jr
both of these commissions next year,
the appointments will continue to be
of a meritorious caliber.
Another question that interests me
greatly is that of Student councilmen taking sides. In questions com•ing before .the council relative to the
honor system and such which are
clearly defined as being right—or
being wrong, then members of the
council should immediately take a
stand on these questions and have the
courage to stick to their convictions.
However in those questions which
have no defined right or wrong, but
are determined so by concensus of
opinion in majority rule, the members of the council should endeavor
to sit on the fence and hear all sides
to this 'type of question with every
angle presented. Then remembering
that his duty is to, represent the
members of his class who elected him
to office, rather than any organization on the campus, any single faction, or administrative authority, the
councilman should take a stand
which in a representative one—not
only of himself as an individual but
others around him. In this regard
if the Student council is forced to
act as a dictator, the underriruate
stridefitS'stidliffrapprOat'll theTr councilmen and communicate their ideas
to him. Class officers can serve usefully as spokesmen in this effect.
Much can be accomplished by this
means of tactful representation—
however, if it is not used, the answer
is entirely in the hands of the Student council.

, scores mean anything, the Jays
should be in for a sound drubbing.

Beta Kappa
TWENTY - EIGHT NEW MEMbers were initiated into the Alpha
Chapter of Maryland Phi Beta
Kappa, at initiation ceremonies held
last Friday night at the Hopkins
Faculty club. Dr 5 0 Mast, president of the local chapter, acted as
chairman, and Dr H S Jennings, director of the Hoftkins Zoological
Walters, prolaboratory, and
fessor of zoology gave the address.
Speaking on "Some Aspects of the
Nature of Man," Dr Jennings emphasized the uniqueness of almost
every individual making up society,
and the consequent conclusion, that
there can be no regular law laid
down either by natural scientists, or
by social scientists, to predict the
exact behavior of man at a given
time.

and any denotative or connotative

The present Student council devoted much time and thought to the
trthancement of a well functioning
honor system. The Engineering and
the Arts and Sciences and Business
Schools Honor Commissions were
appointed. These appointments were
suggested and discussed by the council. The appointments were in no
sense political.
The Commissions
have functioned beautifully and have
produced material results in the educational drive toward honor. If I
have anything to do with either Jr
both of these commissions next year,
the appointments will continue to be
of a meritorious caliber.
Another question that interests me
greatly is that of Student councilmen taking sides. In questions com•ing before .the council relative to the
honor system and such which are
clearly defined as being right—or
being wrong, then members of the
council should immediately take a
stand on these questions and have the
courage to stick to their convictions.
However in those questions which
have no defined right or wrong, but
are determined so by concensus of
opinion in majority rule, the members of the council should endeavor
to sit on the fence and hear all sides
to this 'type of question with every
angle presented. Then remembering
that his duty is to, represent the
members of his class who elected him
to office, rather than any organization on the campus, any single faction, or administrative authority, the
councilman should take a stand
which in a representative one—not
only of himself as an individual but
others around him. In this regard
if the Student council is forced to
act as a dictator, the underriruate
stridefitS'stidliffrapprOat'll theTr councilmen and communicate their ideas
to him. Class officers can serve usefully as spokesmen in this effect.
Much can be accomplished by this
means of tactful representation—
however, if it is not used, the answer
is entirely in the hands of the Student council.
